 <title>Georgia Launches U.S.-led Military Drill Despite Russian Warning</title>
 <link>http://www.newsweek.com/georgia-launches-us-led-military-drill-despite-russian-warning-459272</link>
 <description><p>Georgia has launched a two-week military exercise with NATO allies led by the U.S. despite Russia’s warnings that they have been following the preparations and consider Georgia’s actions provocative.</p>
<p>Relations between Georgia and Russia took a severe turn for the worse in 2008 when, after years of political deadlock with separatists in two of its regions near its border with Russia, Georgia opted for a military solution. In response, Russia, who had supported separatists in both regions—South Ossetia and Abkhazia—advanced forces to fight Georgian troops away from the territories. Since then Russia has moved towards effectively incorporating the two regions under its leadership, while Georgia has refused to recognize them as anything but its sovereign territory, temporarily out of its control.</p>
<p>Meanwhile, Georgia has also actively sought to join NATO, despite Russia repeatedly making clear that it considers any increase of NATO presence near its borders a threat.</p>
<p>In the latest of these moves, Georgia kicked off the 2016 <a  href="http://www.eur.army.mil/noblepartner/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> Noble Partner exercise</a> on Wednesday. The drill sees 500 Georgian, 650 U.S. and 150 U.K. soldiers train together to improve the military-to-military relationship between NATO states and Georgia and to raise Georgia’s standards to NATO levels.</p>
<p>Russia’s <a  href="http://ria.ru/world/20160506/1428076732.html" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> Ministry of Foreign Affairs</a> responded to the drill by accusing Georgia of harboring “revanchist ambitions” and condemning NATO’s “provocative step” to side with Georgia.</p>
<p>Both NATO and Russia have reinforced military assets near their mutual borders since Russia’s annexation of Ukraine’s Crimea in 2014 and both sides have insisted <a href="http://europe.newsweek.com/nato-russia-preparing-conflict-warns-report-331499"> their measures are defensive</a>.</p>
<p>Georgia has wanted NATO membership since before its altercation with Russia in 2008, however, the country is yet to be given a deadline on when it can expect to join the alliance. The protracted process of Georgia’s admittance has <a href="http://www.newsweek.com/putin-vetoing-which-countries-can-join-nato-402699"> fueled speculation that NATO is unwilling</a> to anger Russia, though NATO allies have been able to point to the fact that Georgia does not have full control over all of its regions as a reason why embarking on an official alliance with the country would be difficult.</p>
</description>

 <title>Methane Pollution Addressed With First-Ever EPA Rules</title>
 <link>http://www.newsweek.com/methane-pollution-addressed-first-ever-epa-rules-459350</link>
 <description><p><em>This story was originally published by <a  href="http://www.motherjones.com/environment/2016/05/obama-methane-epa" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">Mother Jones</a> and is reproduced here as part of the <a  href="http://climatedesk.org/"   rel="nofollow" target="_blank">Climate Desk collaboration</a>.</em></p>
<p>The Environmental Protection Agency on Thursday released the <a  href="https://www3.epa.gov/airquality/oilandgas/may2016/nsps-finalrule.pdf"  rel="nofollow" target="_blank">final version</a> of new federal rules intended to curb emissions of a powerful greenhouse gas.</p>
<p>Methane, which is the main component of natural gas, had previously been unregulated. There's a mounting pile of evidence suggesting that as the United States relies increasingly on gas via fracking to produce electricity, methane emissions are <a  href="http://www.motherjones.com/environment/2016/02/methane-emissions-aliso-canyon"  rel="nofollow" target="_blank">much higher</a> than most people expected them to be.</p>
<p>That's a problem for the fight against climate change. Methane emissions are far lower than carbon dioxide emissions, and methane survives in the atmosphere for a relatively short period of time. But methane is far more effective at trapping heat than CO2 is, which makes it a significant near-term warming threat. As I <a  href="http://www.motherjones.com/environment/2016/03/did-fracking-ruin-obamas-climate-legacy"  rel="nofollow" target="_blank">reported in a deep dive on methane</a>:</p>
<blockquote><p>When unburned methane leaks into the atmosphere, it can help cause dramatic warming in a relatively short period of time. Methane emissions have long been a missing piece in the country's patchwork climate policy.... The natural gas system produces methane emissions at nearly every step of the process, from the well itself to the pipe that carries gas into your home. Around two-thirds of those emissions are "intentional," meaning they occur during normal use of equipment. For example, some pneumatic gauges use the pressure of natural gas to flip on or off and emit tiny puffs of methane when they do so. The other one-third comes from so-called "fugitive" emissions, aka leaks, that happen when a piece of equipment cracks or otherwise fails.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>The lack of regulations on methane was one reason why President Barack Obama's climate strategy, which hinges on swapping the country's coal consumption for natural gas, has been frowned upon by some environmentalists. Even today's regulations are <a  href="http://www.motherjones.com/environment/2015/01/climate-change-methane-obama-criticism"  rel="nofollow" target="_blank">only a partial solution</a>, since they apply only to new and modified natural gas infrastructure, not systems that already exist. And by some analysts' reckoning, more than 70 percent of gas-sector methane emissions from now until 2025 will come from sources that already exist.</p>
<p>Still, the regulation announced today achieves one of the final remaining big items on Obama's climate checklist. It aims to reduce gas-sector methane emissions 40 to 45 percent below 2012 levels by 2025 by tightening the allowed emissions from pumps, compressors, wells and other infrastructure; requiring more frequent surveys for leaks; and implementing a data-gathering survey that will give officials and companies a better understanding of just how much methane leakage there really is. The EPA expects the regulations to cost $530 million by 2025 but to produce $690 million in environmental benefits.</p>
</description>

 <title>'Game of Thrones' Fans Want $20 Million to 'Fix' Dorne Scenes</title>
 <link>http://www.newsweek.com/game-thrones-fans-want-20-million-fix-dorne-scenes-459208</link>
 <description><p>Reddit has developed a reputation as <a  href="https://www.reddit.com/r/asoiaf/comments/22f6lx/spoilers_all_benioff_weiss_are_screwing_with_us/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> being something of a hub</a> [spoilers] for disgruntled <a href="http://europe.newsweek.com/search?q=game+of+thrones&amp;op=Search"><em> Game of Thrones</em></a> fans. As acclaimed as the show is, creators David Benioff and D.B.Weiss haven’t been able to please everyone—over the last six seasons there’s been criticism of casting choices, the graphic sex and deviating too far from George R.R.Martin’s <a href="http://europe.newsweek.com/game-thrones-george-r-r-martin-reveals-new-sample-chapter-458475"><em> A Song of Ice and Fire</em> novels</a>, on which the series is based.</p>
<p>But while most fans would probably vent on the Internet and be done with it, one group of viewers has taken matters into their own hands. David Panfilo, who was a question writer on the official <a href="http://europe.newsweek.com/hbo-making-life-lot-harder-games-thrones-pirates-457957"><em> Game of Thrones</em></a> trivia game, director/writer Sean Ireland, Vincent Pezzutti, Teela Wyman and Jonathan Ying have launched a <a  href="https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1833467562/fixing-dorne" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> Kickstarter campaign</a> to raise $20 million—no, really, 20 million—to reshoot scenes set in fictional country Dorne. The creative bunch feel the home of fallen Princes Oberyn and Doran hasn’t been done justice on the small screen.</p>
<p>Now, there may be a temptation to dismiss the project, titled “Fixing Dorne”, as absurd based on the monetary goal alone, but the group feel they are justified in their reasoning. “The costume and set designers for the show did a fantastic job with the Dornish culture,” the campaign concedes, but “many of our qualms come from strange writing choices and what seemed like a misallocation of creative resources.”</p>
<p>Among the things the group hopes to “fix” is writing the Sand Snakes—the group of deadly female assassins that helped kill Myrcella Lannister in season five—to be more three-dimensional and not “just catty comic relief.” In a show that has so many strong, complex female characters with various shades of moral ambiguity—Cersei Lannister and Arya Stark among them—perhaps the criticism of the Sand Snakes isn’t unwarranted. The season six premiere, for example, played for laughs when Nymeria said, “You’re a greedy bitch, you know that?” to her sister Obara after the latter killed Trystane Martell.</p>
<p>

  
  <span class="figure embed" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" itemprop="image" itemid="http://s.newsweek.com/sites/www.newsweek.com/files/styles/embed-lg/public/2016/05/12/game-thrones-fixing-dorne.png">
    <picture itemprop="contentUrl" width="680" height="322" class="mapping-embed"><!--[if IE 9]><video style="display: none;"><![endif]--><source srcset="http://s.newsweek.com/sites/www.newsweek.com/files/styles/full/public/2016/05/12/game-thrones-fixing-dorne.png 1x" media="(min-width: 1200px)"></source><source srcset="http://s.newsweek.com/sites/www.newsweek.com/files/styles/embed-lg/public/2016/05/12/game-thrones-fixing-dorne.png 1x" media="(min-width: 992px)"></source><source srcset="http://s.newsweek.com/sites/www.newsweek.com/files/styles/embed-tablet/public/2016/05/12/game-thrones-fixing-dorne.png 1x" media="(min-width: 768px)"></source><source srcset="http://s.newsweek.com/sites/www.newsweek.com/files/styles/embed-tablet/public/2016/05/12/game-thrones-fixing-dorne.png 1x" media="(min-width: 481px)"></source><source srcset="http://s.newsweek.com/sites/www.newsweek.com/files/styles/embed-sm/public/2016/05/12/game-thrones-fixing-dorne.png 1x" media="(min-width: 0px)"></source><!--[if IE 9]></video><![endif]--><img itemprop="contentUrl" width="680" height="322" class="mapping-embed" src="http://s.newsweek.com/sites/www.newsweek.com/files/styles/embed-lg/public/2016/05/12/game-thrones-fixing-dorne.png" alt="Game of Thrones - Fixing Dorne" title="" /></picture><span class="figcaption">
                  <span class="caption" itemprop="caption">
            A sketch of how the Fixing Dorne team imagine the Sand Snakes looking.          </span>
                          <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            Teela Wyman          </span>
              </span>
      </span>
</p>
<p>So, how exactly do they intend to pull off their reimagining of Dorne? The team hope to reshoot scenes set in Dorne and allow viewers to watch them within the context of each <em> Game of Thrones</em> episode. So, instead of watching the Dorne scene on the show, you’d pause the episode and watch Fixing Dorne’s scene instead. It’s <a  href="http://www.forbes.com/sites/jeffbercovici/2014/07/10/using-a-second-screen-while-watching-tv-is-now-the-norm/#556d43333a99" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> second-screen viewing</a> taken to a whole new level.</p>
<p>The $20 million budget, they say, would help ensure they can match the show’s high production values (thought to be $10 million an episode) and could even be put towards hiring some of the original <em> Game of Thrones</em> stars such as Jaime Lannister actor Nikolaj Coster-Waldau and Bronn actor Jerome Flynn, who spent most of season five in Dorne. You can’t accuse them of being unambitious.</p>
<p></p><div class="embed-responsive embed-responsive-16by9"><iframe frameborder="0" scrolling="no" allowfullscreen="1" class="embed-responsive-item" src="http://video.ibt.com/share/17834?publisher=nw"></iframe></div>
<p>The project has already managed to gain some steam, raising over $20,000. However, it’s still a long way off its goal.</p>
<p>Of course, all of this is subject to legal opposition from HBO, but barring any intervention—and assuming they manage to raise their eight-figure goal—look for Fixing Dorne to hit a screen near you sometime in 2018.</p>
</description>

 <title>Online Auction for Gun Used to Kill Trayvon Martin Apparently Halted</title>
 <link>http://www.newsweek.com/online-auction-gun-used-kill-trayvon-martin-apparently-halted-459358</link>
 <description><p>An online auction for the gun used to kill Trayvon Martin appears to have been halted. The website GunBroker.com now <a  href="http://www.gunbroker.com/Auction/ViewItem.aspx?Item=558112068" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> returns an error</a> at the link where George Zimmerman listed the Kel-Tec PF-9 9mm handgun he used in the 2012 shooting, with a note saying, “Sorry, but the item you have requested is no longer in the system.”</p>
<p>

  
  <span class="figure embed" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" itemprop="image" itemid="http://s.newsweek.com/sites/www.newsweek.com/files/styles/embed-lg/public/2016/05/12/screen-shot-2016-05-12-1.png">
    <picture itemprop="contentUrl" width="961" height="473" class="mapping-embed"><!--[if IE 9]><video style="display: none;"><![endif]--><source srcset="http://s.newsweek.com/sites/www.newsweek.com/files/styles/full/public/2016/05/12/screen-shot-2016-05-12-1.png 1x" media="(min-width: 1200px)"></source><source srcset="http://s.newsweek.com/sites/www.newsweek.com/files/styles/embed-lg/public/2016/05/12/screen-shot-2016-05-12-1.png 1x" media="(min-width: 992px)"></source><source srcset="http://s.newsweek.com/sites/www.newsweek.com/files/styles/embed-tablet/public/2016/05/12/screen-shot-2016-05-12-1.png 1x" media="(min-width: 768px)"></source><source srcset="http://s.newsweek.com/sites/www.newsweek.com/files/styles/embed-tablet/public/2016/05/12/screen-shot-2016-05-12-1.png 1x" media="(min-width: 481px)"></source><source srcset="http://s.newsweek.com/sites/www.newsweek.com/files/styles/embed-sm/public/2016/05/12/screen-shot-2016-05-12-1.png 1x" media="(min-width: 0px)"></source><!--[if IE 9]></video><![endif]--><img itemprop="contentUrl" width="961" height="473" class="mapping-embed" src="http://s.newsweek.com/sites/www.newsweek.com/files/styles/embed-lg/public/2016/05/12/screen-shot-2016-05-12-1.png" alt="Screen Shot 2016-05-12 at 1" title="" /></picture><span class="figcaption">
                  <span class="caption" itemprop="caption">
            The gun George Zimmerman used in the shooting of Trayvon Martin in 2012 appears to have been removed from the website GunBroker.com. A one-day auction for the firearm had been set to begin Thursday morning.           </span>
                          <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            GunBroker.com          </span>
              </span>
      </span>
</p>
<p>Zimmerman—a neighborhood watch volunteer who fatally shot the unarmed black teenager—was <a  href="http://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/14/us/george-zimmerman-verdict-trayvon-martin.html" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> acquitted</a> of second-degree murder and manslaughter. After the Department of Justice returned his gun, he decided to put it up for auction on GunBroker.com.</p>
<p>"I thought it was time to move past the firearm. If I sell it, and it sells, I move past it. Otherwise it's going in a safe for my grandkids, never to be used or seen again,” <a  href="http://bigstory.ap.org/article/e8f22f2835834e768c81567b1d7720fd/pistol-used-trayvon-martin-shooting-be-auctioned" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> he told WOFL-TV</a>.</p>
<p>“This is a piece of American history," he <a  href="http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/05/12/zimmerman-shot-down-by-auction-site-for-trying-to-sell-travyon-martin-gun.html?via=twitter_page" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> reportedly wrote</a> on the auction page, <a  href="http://www.esquire.com/news-politics/news/a44809/george-zimmerman-trayvon-martin-gun-auction/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> claiming that</a> "many have expressed interest in owning and displaying the firearm including The Smithsonian Museum in Washington D.C.” The Smithsonian, however, <a href="https://twitter.com/smithsonian/status/730753431821004800"> vehemently denied</a> any past, present or future interest in purchasing or displaying the item.</p>
<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en"><p dir="ltr" lang="en" xml:lang="en">We have never expressed interest in collecting George Zimmerman’s firearm, and have no plans to ever collect or display it in any museums</p>
<p>	— Smithsonian (@smithsonian) <a href="https://twitter.com/smithsonian/status/730753431821004800">May 12, 2016</a></p></blockquote>
<script async="" src="//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script><p>Listing a <a  href="http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/05/12/zimmerman-shot-down-by-auction-site-for-trying-to-sell-travyon-martin-gun.html?via=twitter_page" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> starting price of $5,000</a>, Zimmerman wrote that a portion of the proceeds from the sale would go toward a number of causes: to “fight [Black Lives Matter] violence against Law Enforcement officers, ensure the demise of [the attorney who prosecuted him] Angela Correy’s [sic] persecution career and Hillary Clinton’s anti-firearm rhetoric.”</p>
<p>The one-day auction had been scheduled to run from 11 a.m. ET on Thursday until the same time Friday, but the pistol disappeared from the site almost as soon as it began, <a  href="http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/05/12/zimmerman-shot-down-by-auction-site-for-trying-to-sell-travyon-martin-gun.html?via=twitter_page" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"><em> The Daily Beast</em> reports</a>. GunBroker, which bills itself as the “world’s largest online auction of firearms, parts &amp; accessories,” had its <a href="https://twitter.com/GunBroker"> Twitter account</a> set to private Thursday and <a  href="http://www.esquire.com/news-politics/news/a44809/george-zimmerman-trayvon-martin-gun-auction/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> did not immediately release a public statement</a> about the removal of the listing from its site.</p>

 <description><p>The life of former world no.1 Maria Sharapova still seems to be pretty sweet in spite of serving a provisional ban from tennis for doping.</p>
<p>Sharapova, 29, has been absent from the court since March 12 after testing positive for the banned substance of <a href="http://www.newsweek.com/maria-sharapova-meldonium-what-meldonium-436525"> meldonium</a> at the Australian Open in January.</p>
<p>But the five-time Grand-Slam champion has spent her new-found free time launching a first range of chocolate from her candy company, Sugarpova.</p>
<p>There remains a chance that Sharapova <a href="http://www.newsweek.com/maria-sharapova-meldonium-wimbledon-450583"> will feature at the Wimbledon Championships</a>, which run from June 27 through July 10, with her chocolate bars also on sale.</p>
<p>There are plans for the  bars, which go on sale from Sunday (May 15) and cost between $4.99 and $5.99, to be available in a pop-up Sugarpova store at Wimbledon Village.</p>
<p>An official launch of the product is set to take place in the United States later this month.</p>

 <title>The Government Must Support UK Nurses or Face Shortage</title>
 <link>http://www.newsweek.com/unison-government-must-support-uk-nurses-459287</link>
 <description><p>Most people, at some point in their lives, have needed a nurse.</p>
<p>They are there at births and deaths, and at difficult times in between. They care for us when we are sick and help us get back on our feet again.</p>
<p>They’re the world’s largest group of health professionals, an absolutely essential part of every health service around the world—and we celebrate them each year, on May 12, International Nurses Day.</p>
<p>Of course nurses face many different challenges.</p>
<p>Some are forced to work in the most difficult and trying circumstances imaginable, putting themselves in great personal danger in order to save the lives of others. In April, in Syria, an <a href="http://www.newsweek.com/un-hospital-attacks-aleppo-burning-455138"> air strike hit Aleppo’s al-Quds hospital</a>, killing staff and patients alike. Over 700 medical professionals have died in Syria since the start of the conflict, including many nurses. Wherever there is conflict there will be nurses saving lives and providing care and comfort for those in incredible pain.</p>
<p>Indeed, the reason why International Nurses Day is celebrated today is because Florence Nightingale—perhaps history’s most famous wartime nurse—was born on this day.</p>
<p>Yet it’s not just in warzones where nurses <a href="http://www.newsweek.com/ebola-nurse-pauline-cafferkey-readmitted-hospital-429365"> put their lives on the line</a>. Others put themselves at risk in other ways, like those who traveled from around the world to fight West Africa’s recent Ebola outbreak, looking after those people ravaged by a cruel and <a href="http://www.newsweek.com/ebola-guinea-quarantine-816-people-latest-flare-439376"> highly contagious virus</a>. Some of those nurses succumbed to the virus themselves—making the ultimate sacrifice in the pursuit of saving the lives of others.</p>
<p>That urge to save lives drives nurses worldwide, yet their care is not just about treatment, it is also about prevention. Immunisation nurses save countless lives around the world and help eliminate contagious, treatable disease, helping the world drive down mortality rates.</p>
<p>In the UK nurses face difficulties of their own in an overstretched and underfunded National Health Service. An ageing population means the strain on Britain’s health service is only going to become more acute, putting more pressure on the hard-working nurses who work around the clock for relatively low wages.</p>
<p>As Britain’s largest health union, UNISON has always been quick to point out the importance of nursing as a profession.</p>
<p>Yet the U.K. government has failed to stand up for nurses and nursing, exacerbating an already serious nursing shortage by axing the NHS bursary that allowed student nurses to train. The government should be busting a gut to recruit more student nurses. And yet the government’s desperate attempt to make its numbers add up means that the future of the nursing profession, nurses’ livelihoods and the NHS have been placed in jeopardy.</p>
<p>Senseless cuts like this show that even in wealthy nations nursing as a profession is at risk, and must be fought for and defended.</p>
<p>Today is the day we set aside to remember the work that nurses do. The times they have cared for us, when they have gone above and beyond the call of duty, when they have saved lives and cared for those in need. But the nursing profession needs our thoughts and our support not just today, but each and every day. To protect their jobs and pay, and to ensure they can provide the best standard of care by working in a clean, safe and healthy environment.</p>
<p>After all, when they have given us so much, giving them our wholehearted support is the very least we can do in return.</p>
<p><em>David Prentis is the General Secretary of <a  href="https://www.unison.org.uk/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">UNISON</a>, on of the U.K.'s largest trade unions.</em></p>
</description>

 <title>Radiohead, 'Hail to the Thief': Newsweek's Original Album Review</title>
 <link>http://www.newsweek.com/radiohead-hail-thief-newsweeks-original-album-review-459236</link>
 <description><p><em>In celebration of Radiohead's new album, </em><a href="http://www.newsweek.com/radiohead-moon-shaped-pool-review-458324">A Moon Shaped Pool</a><em>,</em> <em>we're digging through our archives and republishing Devin Gordon's 2003 review of </em>Hail to the Thief<i>, the band's sixth album. This review originally appeared in the June 9, 2003, magazine with the headline "We Regret to Inform You That Radiohead Still Sounds Weird."</i></p>
<p>

  
  <span class="figure embed" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" itemprop="image" itemid="http://s.newsweek.com/sites/www.newsweek.com/files/styles/embed-lg/public/2016/05/12/hail-thief.png">
    <picture itemprop="contentUrl" width="961" height="331" class="mapping-embed"><!--[if IE 9]><video style="display: none;"><![endif]--><source srcset="http://s.newsweek.com/sites/www.newsweek.com/files/styles/full/public/2016/05/12/hail-thief.png 1x" media="(min-width: 1200px)"></source><source srcset="http://s.newsweek.com/sites/www.newsweek.com/files/styles/embed-lg/public/2016/05/12/hail-thief.png 1x" media="(min-width: 992px)"></source><source srcset="http://s.newsweek.com/sites/www.newsweek.com/files/styles/embed-tablet/public/2016/05/12/hail-thief.png 1x" media="(min-width: 768px)"></source><source srcset="http://s.newsweek.com/sites/www.newsweek.com/files/styles/embed-tablet/public/2016/05/12/hail-thief.png 1x" media="(min-width: 481px)"></source><source srcset="http://s.newsweek.com/sites/www.newsweek.com/files/styles/embed-sm/public/2016/05/12/hail-thief.png 1x" media="(min-width: 0px)"></source><!--[if IE 9]></video><![endif]--><img itemprop="contentUrl" width="961" height="331" class="mapping-embed" src="http://s.newsweek.com/sites/www.newsweek.com/files/styles/embed-lg/public/2016/05/12/hail-thief.png" alt="Hail to the Thief" title="" /></picture><span class="figcaption">
                  <span class="caption" itemprop="caption">
            Our 2003 review of "Hail to the Thief."          </span>
                          <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            Newsweek/June 3, 2003          </span>
              </span>
      </span>
</p>
<p>Music critics are already calling Radiohead's new album, <em>Hail to the Thief</em>, a return to the straight-ahead guitar rock of the Oxford quintet's early days. It makes me wonder: Did I get the wrong CD in the mail? True, <em>Hail </em>has a few almost-radio-friendly tracks<em>—</em>like the album-opening "2 + 2 = 5," a mini-symphony that builds to an ecstatic climax, and the dripping-with-dread finale, "A Wolf at the Door." But there's little else to suggest that Radiohead has abandoned the experimental left turn it took after the 1997 classic <em>OK Computer</em>. Like <em><a href="http://www.newsweek.com/radiohead-kid-newsweeks-original-album-review-458704">Kid A</a> </em>and <em>Amnesiac</em>, the two CDs that followed, <em>Hail </em>is both dazzling and frustrating; it refuses to give up its secrets even after a dozen listens.</p>
<p>Singer Thom Yorke has a gorgeous, yearning voice, but instead of drawing you close, he often uses it to freeze you out. He's always written casually vicious lyrics<em>—</em>"We hope that you choke" from <em>OK Computer</em> is a personal favorite<em>—</em>but <em>Hail to the Thief</em> seems bent on setting new records for emotional distance ("We can wipe you out anytime"; "We are accidents waiting to happen"). The intention is to evoke the way modernity slowly grinds people to dust<em>—</em>one of this group's career-long obsessions. Still, on the first single, "There There," when Yorke repeats "Just because you feel it, doesn't mean it's there" again and again, you feel embarrassed for getting so engrossed, as if you've slept with someone too quickly. Artists warning us not to trust our response to their art? Ouch. Radiohead may never stop being a band to admire, but they're no longer a band you can love.</p>
</description>

 <title>Prince's Ex-Wives Hold Memorial for Celebrity Friends in Los Angeles</title>
 <link>http://www.newsweek.com/princes-ex-wives-hold-memorial-celebrity-friends-los-angeles-459175</link>
 <description><p>Nearly a month after His Purpleness’ death, <a href="http://europe.newsweek.com/prince-doctor-who-prescribed-singer-medication-death-named-458334"> Prince</a> was memorialized by his closest friends in Hollywood at a secretive gathering on Wednesday night.</p>
<p>The event was held at the Samuel Goldwyn Theater in Beverly Hills and was organized by <a href="http://europe.newsweek.com/prince-minnesota-likeness-exploitation-law-proposed-musicians-honor-457775"> Prince’s</a> ex-wives Manuela Testolini and Mayte Garcia, reports <a  href="http://www.eonline.com/news/764194/prince-s-ex-wives-manuela-testolini-and-mayte-garcia-hold-star-studded-private-memorial-for-late-legend" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> E! News</a>. The “Purple Rain” singer was married to Garcia from 1996 to 1999. They had one child, a son named Boy Gregory, who was born with Pfeiffer syndrome and died a week later in October 1996. Prince married Testolini in 2001 and they remained together until she filed for divorce in 2006.</p>
<p>Guests included film director Spike Lee, Chic musician Nile Rodgers and Cheryl Boone Isaacs, the president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences (AMPAS), the organization that hands out the Oscars. Performances came from Janelle Monae, a mentee of the iconic musician, and Esperanza Spalding, according to <a  href="http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/7369841/nile-rodgers-spike-lee-prince-memorial" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"><em> Billboard</em></a>.</p>
<p>Lee posted a picture of a purple beret and purple Nike sneakers on his Instagram account on Wednesday. He captioned the picture: “Purple Beret And Purple Kobe's For Prince Memorial Tonight In El LAY." [sic]</p>

 <title>How to Host Your Own Eurovision Song Contest Party</title>
 <link>http://www.newsweek.com/how-host-your-own-eurovision-song-contest-party-459258</link>
 <description><p>It is that joyous time of year where once again the <a href="http://europe.newsweek.com/eurovision-2016-14-influential-music-hotspots-host-city-stockholm-459014"> Eurovision Song Contest</a> is upon us in all its glitter-infused glory. The annual <a href="http://europe.newsweek.com/russia-and-ukraine-set-battle-it-out-eurovision-459148"> singing competition</a> pitting Europe’s good and great—and, er, the odd car crash—against each other is not just a television program, but an entire event in and of itself. An event that is befitting a viewing party, as many across Europe will be doing this weekend.</p>
<p>If we must lament Great Britain again earning <em> nil points </em> from rivals across the continent, we may as well do it with a cocktail in hand, right?</p>
<p>

  
  <span class="figure embed" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" itemprop="image" itemid="http://s.newsweek.com/sites/www.newsweek.com/files/styles/embed-lg/public/2016/05/12/swedish-meatballs.jpg">

                  <span class="caption" itemprop="caption">
            As Stockholm hosts Eurovision, enjoy some Swedish meatballs.          </span>
                          <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            JONATHAN NACKSTRAND/AFP/Getty          </span>
              </span>
      </span>
</p>
<p>This year’s <a href="http://europe.newsweek.com/russians-go-wild-hit-about-loving-someone-putin-450578"> Eurovision</a> is hosted in Stockholm after Sweden’s victory in 2015 with singer Frans’ track “If I Were Sorry.”</p>
<p>Need some ideas to host your own Eurovision party? Look no further...</p>
<h3><strong>The date</strong></h3>
<p>If you’re sending out a save the date, make sure you’ve got the date and time correct: Eurovision airs on Saturday (May 14) at 8pm British summer time. In the U.K. you can watch the bum-numbing three-and-a-half-hour broadcast on BBC One with commentary from Graham Norton.</p>
<p>

  
  <span class="figure embed" itemscope="" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" itemprop="image" itemid="http://s.newsweek.com/sites/www.newsweek.com/files/styles/embed-lg/public/2016/05/12/conchita-wurst.jpg">
    <picture itemprop="contentUrl" width="961" height="641" class="mapping-embed"><!--[if IE 9]><video style="display: none;"><![endif]--><source srcset="http://s.newsweek.com/sites/www.newsweek.com/files/styles/full/public/2016/05/12/conchita-wurst.jpg 1x" media="(min-width: 1200px)"></source><source srcset="http://s.newsweek.com/sites/www.newsweek.com/files/styles/embed-lg/public/2016/05/12/conchita-wurst.jpg 1x" media="(min-width: 992px)"></source><source srcset="http://s.newsweek.com/sites/www.newsweek.com/files/styles/embed-tablet/public/2016/05/12/conchita-wurst.jpg 1x" media="(min-width: 768px)"></source><source srcset="http://s.newsweek.com/sites/www.newsweek.com/files/styles/embed-tablet/public/2016/05/12/conchita-wurst.jpg 1x" media="(min-width: 481px)"></source><source srcset="http://s.newsweek.com/sites/www.newsweek.com/files/styles/embed-sm/public/2016/05/12/conchita-wurst.jpg 1x" media="(min-width: 0px)"></source><!--[if IE 9]></video><![endif]--><img itemprop="contentUrl" width="961" height="641" class="mapping-embed" src="http://s.newsweek.com/sites/www.newsweek.com/files/styles/embed-lg/public/2016/05/12/conchita-wurst.jpg" alt="Conchita Wurst" title="" /></picture><span class="figcaption">
                  <span class="caption" itemprop="caption">
            Dress up as Eurovision 2014 winner Conchita Wurst for your party.          </span>
                          <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            Ragnar Singsaas/Getty          </span>
              </span>
      </span>
</p>
<h3><strong>The food</strong></h3>
<p>Sweden hosting Eurovision is prime excuse to head to IKEA and pick up their frozen <a  href="http://www.ikea.com/gb/en/catalog/products/70028680/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> Swedish meatballs</a>. For an authentic Swedish meal, serve your meatballs with <a  href="http://www.ikea.com/gb/en/catalog/products/10308626/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> lingonberry jam</a>, a sweet-and-sour sauce not dissimilar from cranberry sauce. For more Swedish food ideas <a  href="https://sweden.se/culture-traditions/10-things-to-know-about-swedish-food/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> click here</a>—we’re salivating at that green princess cake.</p>
<p>Of course, Eurovision represents countries across Europe, so you could put on an intercontinental feast that would put any hotel breakfast buffet to shame. Think <a  href="https://www.nigella.com/recipes/cocktail-sausages" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> cocktail sausages</a> for Britain, <a  href="http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2010/jan/18/guide-jamon-iberico-spanish-ham" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> jamón ibérico</a> for Spain and <a  href="http://www.jamieoliver.com/recipes/pork-recipes/souvlaki-wicked-kebabs/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> fresh souvlaki</a> with tzatziki for Greece.</p>
<h3><strong>The drink</strong></h3>
<p>Eurovision is a three-and-a-half-hour broadcast. That’s a <em> lot </em> of singing. No-one will blame you for having a bottle of wine handy. Or, if you’re feeling brave and don’t mind mixing your drinks, you could create stock drinks such as a <a  href="http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/wordofmouth/2013/jun/19/how-to-make-the-perfect-sangria" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> Spanish sangria</a> , Irish whisky with Coke and German beer.</p>
<p>For those that want to wow their friends and family with specially created cocktails, the <a  href="http://www.bbcgoodfood.com/recipes/collection/eurovision-party" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> BBC</a> has a selection of recipes including a mouthwatering prosecco and elderflower cocktail.</p>
<p>By the way, make sure you have <em> plenty </em> of drinks on hand because you’ll need them (see the entertainment section below).</p>
<h3><strong>The costume</strong></h3>
<p>Need a theme for your Eurovision party? Have your guests dress up as past Eurovision performers. Eurovision 2014 winner Conchita Wurst requires little more than a <a  href="http://www.unionjackwear.co.uk/accessories-c5/eurovision-song-contest-party-c114/conchita-wurst-eurovision-fancy-dress-kit-wig-and-beard-and-eyelashs-costume-beared-lady-p2302" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> wig and a fake beard</a> (and not even that if you have your own).</p>
<p>And there are costumes of the most iconic Eurovision winners ever, ABBA (they won with “Waterloo” in 1974), in shops and <a  href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/Dancing-Queen-ABBA-Costume-10-14/dp/B006W6DVM0" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> online outlets</a> everywhere.</p>
<p>The key to a great Eurovision costume is to <em> go big</em>: Dramatic makeup, glitter, bellbottoms, shoulderpads, wigs and platform boots.</p>
<h3><strong>The music</strong></h3>
<p>The broadcast doesn’t start until 8pm but you can begin the party early by queuing up a playlist on Spotify. Listen to <a  href="https://play.spotify.com/user/eurovision14/playlist/0GQ9bAhdPV2LEEc7eRqTs0?play=true&amp;utm_source=open.spotify.com&amp;utm_medium=open" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> past winners’ tracks</a> or relive all 40 entries from the <a  href="https://play.spotify.com/user/b469213/playlist/3yUgUhvdHXT2U69UGPJ2e3" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> 2015 competition</a>.</p>
<p>And with <a  href="http://www.itv.com/news/2016-05-11/justin-timberlake-to-perform-at-eurovision-song-contest/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> news</a> that Eurovision is to get some U.S. flavor with a guest performance from superstar Justin Timberlake, maybe crank up a playlist of his <a  href="https://play.spotify.com/artist/31TPClRtHm23RisEBtV3X7" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> greatest hits</a>.</p>
<h3><strong>The entertainment</strong></h3>
<p>What would Eurovision be without a drinking game? If you’re watching with friends of a legal drinking age, take a shot every time one of the following happens:</p>
<ol><li>
<p>There’s a wind machine</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Someone cries</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>There’s a key change</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>There are firework</p>
</li>
</ol><p>And once the results pour in, there’s even more opportunity to drink. Although if you take a shot every time Great Britain earns <em> douze points</em> you might remain sober…</p>
<p>Not a drinker? That’s fine, too. Test your friends’ knowledge of Eurovision trivia with <a  href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/quiz/2015/apr/02/eurovision-song-contest-quiz-60th-anniversary" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> this great quiz</a> or perhaps fire up the karaoke machine for some Eurovision-themed singalongs.</p>
<p>Happy Eurovision.</p>
</description>

 <title>Nigeria Removes Fuel Subsidy, Prompts Mixed Reactions</title>
 <link>http://www.newsweek.com/nigeria-removes-fuel-subsidy-prompts-mixed-reactions-459159</link>
 <description><p>Nigeria’s government has announced the removal of a fuel subsidy, meaning that petrol prices are to rise by 66 percent, in a decision that has provoked mixed responses.</p>
<p>The cost of petrol will rise from 86.5 naira ($0.43) to 145 naira ($0.73) per litre after the subsidy—which costs the Nigerian government $2.7 million per day, <a  href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-36274402" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> according to the BBC</a>—was removed. The Nigerian Petroleum Ministry said <a href="https://twitter.com/FMPRng"> in a statement</a> that there was no provision for the subsidy in the 2016 budget—which was <a href="http://europe.newsweek.com/nigerias-buhari-finally-passes-2016-budget-456739"> finally approved by President Muhammadu Buhari on Friday</a> after first being proposed in December 2015—and that the slight rebound in the cost of oil had forced the government’s hand.</p>
<p>Nigeria is experiencing a severe fuel shortage, with <a href="http://europe.newsweek.com/nigerian-minister-summoned-senate-explain-fuel-scarcity-441678"> consumers queuing for hours outside gas stations</a> and often paying way over the new price for black-market products. The West African country, the continent’s biggest oil producer, has been unable to meet demand due to several factors, including <a href="http://europe.newsweek.com/nigeria-five-security-personnel-killed-niger-delta-union-considers-pulling-out-458464"> increased attacks on oil pipelines in the Niger Delta</a> that have forced the evacuation and shutdown of some facilities. “We share the pains of Nigerians but...the inherited difficulties of the past and the challenges of current times imply that we must take difficult decisions on these sorts of critical national issues,” said Petroleum Minister Emmanuel Kachikwu <a href="https://www.facebook.com/TheAsoVilla/?fref=ts"> in a statement on Wednesday</a>.</p>
<p>A similar decision to remove the subsidy in January 2012 by former President Goodluck Jonathan <a  href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jan/16/nigeria-restores-fuel-subsidy-protests" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> prompted nationwide protests</a> by consumers and strikes by labor unions, with at least 10 people being killed in violent demonstrations. One of the unions that went on strike in 2012, the Nigeria Labor Congress (NLC), rejected the “unilateral” increase, which it said represents the “height of insensitivity and impunity and shall be resisted by the NLC and its civil society allies,” <a  href="http://www.premiumtimesng.com/news/top-news/203264-nlc-talks-tough-says-shall-resist-increase.html" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> Nigeria’s Premium Times reported</a> on Wednesday.</p>
<p>But some Nigerians on social media expressed the view that the removal of the subsidy was a necessary step towards relieving the fuel shortage. Others, such as Nigerian senator Ben Murray-Bruce—a member of the opposition People’s Democratic Party—took the opportunity to poke fun at the Buhari administration.</p>
<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en"><p dir="ltr" lang="en" xml:lang="en">Timing is bad. But there's really no good time for making hard choices. Whats important is making them. <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/FuelSubsidy?src=hash">#FuelSubsidy</a> <a  href="https://t.co/k7jhCH4tlW" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">https://t.co/k7jhCH4tlW</a></p>
<p>	— Amara Nwankpa (@bubusn) <a href="https://twitter.com/bubusn/status/730716228986241024">May 12, 2016</a></p></blockquote>
<script async="" src="//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script><blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en">
<p dir="ltr" lang="en" xml:lang="en">Somebody is asking me for advise on how he can survive fuel price increase. What can I say? Personally I'm even considering buying a horse!</p>
<p>	— Ben Murray-Bruce (@benmurraybruce) <a href="https://twitter.com/benmurraybruce/status/730540424012529664">May 11, 2016</a></p></blockquote>
<script async="" src="//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script><p>According to Malte Liewerscheidt, senior Africa analyst at political risk consultancy Verisk Maplecroft, says that resistance to the subsidy removal is likely to be less pronounced than in 2012. “Paying much more than the official 86.5 naira per liter has been a reality for most Nigerians for a long time, as the subsidized price has rarely been enforced outside [the capital] Abuja and [the biggest city] Lagos,” says Liewerscheidt. “Unions aside, the majority of Nigerians are probably willing to accept a price increase if it means crippling fuel shortages come to an end.</p>
<p>During a <a href="http://europe.newsweek.com/four-issues-christine-lagarde-nigeria-agenda-411912"> visit to Nigeria in January</a>, International Monetary Fund chief Christine Lagarde <a  href="https://www.imf.org/external/np/speeches/2016/010616.htm" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> urged Buhari</a> to do away with the subsidy, saying that “not only do they harm the planet, but they rarely help the poor.” Nigeria is heavily dependent on the oil and gas industry, with petroleum products accounting for more than 90 percent of the value of its exports.</p>
</description>

 <title>God, Cocaine, Money and Forgetting: A Look at Donald Trump's New Economic Adviser</title>
 <link>http://www.newsweek.com/larry-kudlow-donald-trump-economic-adviser-459226</link>
 <description><p>The story of the man who might rewrite America’s tax plan if Donald Trump is elected is, as the mogul might say, really, really fantastic, just terrific.</p>
<p>It’s a story of God, cocaine, money and forgetting—but maybe not in that order. Born at the beginning the baby boom in 1947, Lawrence Alan "Larry" Kudlow—whom Trump recently <a  href="http://news.google.com/news/url?sr=1&amp;sa=t&amp;ct2=us%2F0_0_s_1_0_t&amp;usg=AFQjCNGNFrlu2Gmy8YYQtDqPCobJd6OJhg&amp;did=39e60ab6042bad82&amp;cid=52779104574224&amp;ei=nIk0V4j_NoTd3AGT6aSgBA&amp;rt=STORY&amp;vm=STANDARD&amp;url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.politico.com%2Fstory%2F2016%2F05%2Fdonald-trump-taxes-tax-reform-223041" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> turned to</a> for a revision of his tax package—grew up to be lefty, hairy and against the Vietnam War. He worked on Democratic political campaigns alongside Bill Clinton and Hillary Clinton future campaign chairman John Podesta before he had his first conversion, veered hard right and soon found himself working in Ronald Reagan’s Office of Management and Budget.</p>
<p>After this stint in D.C., Kudlow returned to the private sector in 1987, headed to Wall Street and spent some years like every other debauched executive with an excess of cash and a waterbed in the tail end of the Me Decade: on weeklong <a  href="http://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/04/business/economist-is-said-to-enter-a-six-month-drug-program.html" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">cocaine binges</a>. His drug problem caused him to resign from the investment bank Bear Stearns in 1994.</p>
<p>Conservative intellectual godfather William Buckley, never one to let a fine right-wing mind go to waste, soon scooped him off the sidewalk and appointed him senior economics editor at <em> National Review</em>, the nation’s preeminent conservative publication. </p>
<p>“I loved that, because of <em> National Review</em>’s intellectual atmosphere and interesting people,” Kudlow <a  href="http://www.crisismagazine.com/2000/lawrence-kudlow-how-a-wall-street-star-became-a-catholic" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> told</a> the Catholic publication <em> Crisis Magazine</em> in 2000. “And there is a certain Catholicism that permeates the place.”</p>
<p>But Kudlow kept drinking and snorting, and <em> National Review</em> fired him after a year. He hit rock bottom in 1995 and shipped out for five months in a Minnesota rehab. There, he ditched the coke and booze for good. Upon leaving rehab, he signed up for some Catholic Opus Dei retreats and found he liked the rigor of a conservative, and what some call "cult-like," group that has been likened to Scientology, with ties to fascist organizations in Italy, and which offered spiritual succor to the likes of the late conservative Justice Antonin Scalia.</p>
<p>In 1997, Kudlow was on his knees in a chapel at St. Thomas More Church in New York City, bawling and converting to Catholicism in front of the whole lock-jawed<em> National Review</em> gang, including Buckley, Kate O’Beirne and Peggy Noonan.</p>
<p>“As soon as I saw Christ on the cross, I felt at one with it,” said Kudlow, who was bar mitzvahed at age 13. </p>
<p>He soon found his other true calling as the King of All Right-Wing Economic Media, and today he is a CNBC anchor, has his own live radio program, the syndicated <em> Larry Kudlow Show</em>, airing every Saturday from 10 a.m to 1 p.m. ET, and publishes comments “roughly” once or twice a week to “present detailed economic research analysis of recent economic and political trends and developments,” according to his website.</p>
<p>He also dispenses wisdom privately to “clients” through Kudlow &amp; Company, according to his <a  href="http://kudlow.com/index.php" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> website</a>.</p>
<p>Those investors apparently don’t know or care that Kudlow has been spectacularly wrong on the biggest economic turning points in modern history. Just before the real estate crash that provoked the 2008 global financial meltdown, he ridiculed people predicting that outcome as “bubbleheads” and was still assuring his listeners and viewers after the financial crash that there was nothing to worry about. As late as 2011, he predicted that the Obama administration stimulus program would create “1970s-style stagflation.” Meanwhile, the country has been seeing the lowest inflation in two generations and the lowest interest rates in history.</p>
<p>Trump’s original tax plan—released to ridicule from mainstream economists on both sides of the political spectrum last September—would have cost $10 trillion and given massive tax cuts to the rich. He has since brought on Kudlow and former American Heritage senior economist Stephen Moore—another supply-side disciple—to tinker with it. The two new advisers have, according to <a  href="http://www.bloomberg.com/politics/trackers/2016-05-11/kudlow-moore-advising-trump-to-raise-top-tax-rate-politico" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> Bloomberg</a>, pared down the cost of the plan to $3.8 trillion by raising his top tax rate to 28 percent from 25 percent. This is still an epic bonanza for the super-rich, since the current top tax rate is 39.6 percent. The plan keeps the capital gains tax rate at 15 percent across income levels and lets companies use “immediate expensing of equipment” for tax purposes.</p>
<p>Trump himself has still not released his own tax returns, and on Tuesday he reiterated that he probably will not do so, making him the first presidential candidate in 40 years not to. A Clinton-aligned super PAC on Wednesday said he is less transparent than Richard Nixon—who did release his taxes, even while under audit.</p>
<p>Kudlow has periodically toyed with the idea of running for U.S. Senate in Connecticut, where he has a home. He is not known to have revised his own theories about the trickling down of money from untaxed wealth since the working class revolted against the GOP’s supply-side-hypnotized establishment and nominated Trump.</p>
<p>Kudlow, Moore and Art Laffer (he of the risible “<a  href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laffer_curve" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">Laffer Curve</a>,” a Reagan-era economics graphic that supposedly proved the poor benefit as the rich get richer) formed a “Committee to Unleash American Prosperity” that wielded some influence over the now-vanquished 2016 GOP candidates. Kudlow even hosted vetting dinners in New York last summer and was among the early cheerleaders for the doomed candidacy of Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker.</p>
<p>The summer of 2015 is a long, long time ago now. And while he remembers his Catholic conversion day “really clearly,” Kudlow conceded to <em> Crisis</em>: “I don't remember many things anymore.”</p>
<p>The supply-side purists have been able to maintain the fig leaf that their billionaire patrons needed during the decades in which wealth inequality in America kept rising. Trump himself appears to have benefited from the long-delayed awakening of the middle-class Republican electorate about the economic philosophy that’s robbed them of their prosperity. By selecting two of the discredited Laffer Curve’s biggest cheerleaders as his economic brain trust, Trump is sending up a smoke signal to the party bosses in Washington and in the Koch mansions that he’s still, wink-wink, one of them.</p>
<p>If he’s lucky—and he has been so far—his working- and middle-class supporters have as many holes in their memory as Kudlow does.</p>
</description>

 <title>Brexit: The Movie Is A Libertarian's Wet Dream</title>
 <link>http://www.newsweek.com/brexit-movie-review-nigel-farage-michael-gove-douglas-carswell-eu-referendum-459234</link>
 <description><p>There’s not much that unites everyone in Britain’s fractious “Brexit” campaigns, but if there’s one point they all agree on, it’s the claim to be “anti-establishment.” From <a href="http://europe.newsweek.com/boris-johnson-david-cameron-showdown-eu-457857"> Eton-educated former London Mayor Boris Johnson</a> to sometime City trader and Member of the European Parliament (MEP) Nigel Farage, “Leave” campaigners like to portray themselves as revolting against a shadowy elite.</p>
<p>So <em> Newsweek </em> experienced a little cognitive dissonance at the Wednesday night premiere of pro-Leave documentary <em> Brexit: The Movie</em> at the Odeon cinema in London’s Leicester Square. The venue recently hosted Ben Affleck for the first U.K. outing of <em> Batman V Superman</em>, and the Brexiters were determined to have their own red carpet experience. The champagne poured forth both before and after (when the crowd gossiped to pumping trance music at the “glamorous and decadent” W Hotel bar nearby). The guest list included Margaret Thatcher’s former Chancellor of the Exchequer Nigel Lawson and ex- <em> Daily Telegraph </em> editor Charles Moore. An aide even told shy Tory MEP Daniel Hannan, who entered through a side door, to go out and come back in properly for the benefit of the waiting paparazzi.</p>
<p>But as the film began, the swanky setting made more sense. Forget the <a href="http://europe.newsweek.com/london-mayor-america-sovereignty-brexit-boris-johnson-obama-448607"> referendum campaign rhetoric</a> about preserving British culture and controlling our borders. <em> Brexit: The Movie</em>, which tells the story of the U.K.’s relationship with Brussels through archive footage, dramatic reconstructions, and interviews with a “who’s who” of British Euroskeptics, is ostensibly about democracy but has another more pressing concern: the glittering possibilities of unfettered free trade. It is a paean to high aspirations, low tariffs and even lower taxes. It is a libertarian’s wet dream of Randian proportions.</p>
<p>As presenter and filmmaker Martin Durkin travels around Brussels ( <em> Newsweek</em> admits to laughing when he gets into a taxi at the Eurostar terminal and asks “The EU, sil-vous-plait”). He and a series of talking heads then tell us how the once-great British spirit of enterprise is being strangled by rules and regulations. “The EU,” the film says, “has slid from free trade into crony capitalism and protectionism.” The film reserves particular ire for moves to save national industries from global competition—we see a “French farmer” sporting a comedy beret and a string of onions doing a backroom deal with a Eurocrat. <em> Newsweek</em> doesn’t remember Brexiters being so averse to government intervention during the U.K.’s <a href="http://europe.newsweek.com/tata-management-takeover-steel-business-sajid-javid-port-talbot-449961"> recent steel crisis</a>, when the Leave.EU campaign complained that “EU state aid rules do not allow public support for the rescue and restructuring of companies in difficulty in the steel sector.”</p>
<p>Britain, meanwhile, was apparently at her best in the 19th century, when it became “the pioneer of global free trade.” The 20th century, with its wars and its workers’ rights, put paid to that. Stagnant, nationalized 70s Britain joined the EU, the film argues, because it wanted a bit of post-war Germany’s economic miracle, but instead was shackled with meddling regulations by the pesky French. A sequence that shows Durkin getting up on a typical  day details the number of rules now governing each household object, painting a portrait of “EU man” stymied by red tape. Showers have 91 rules attached to them, apparently (“we’ve all seen psycho: murdering girls like that is now strictly prohibited”).</p>
<p>In some ways this isn’t surprising. The likes of UKIP MEP Douglas Carswell (who features in the film) and Vote Leave campaign director Dominic Cummings have often argued for a classical liberal Brexit vision. Farage is said to hold similar views privately. But the UKIP leader long ago grasped that voters who don’t obsess over trade regulations need other issues to latch on to. He’s always preferred immigration, the likes of Boris Johnson and Michael Gove more often go for the notion of “sovereignty.” (When <em> Newsweek</em> put this to Farage after the film, he dismissed the criticism: “There are lots of different arguments about this,” he said, “That Brexit movie is designed very much at the 5.2 million men and women running small businesses”).</p>
<p>But <em> Brexit: The Movie</em> is perhaps best understood as Britain’s Euroskeptic community talking to itself. It certainly excited the faithful, who whooped through much of Wednesday’s showing, except the bit of archive footage showing former Prime Minister Ted Heath taking the country into the then-EEC, when they shouted “Judas!” And for that, it’s worth seeing. As <em> Newsweek </em> watched Tories, Ukippers and the odd maverick Labourite hobnobbing under the afterparty’s neon lights, the impression was of a new establishment waiting to take on the mantle after June 23. After Brexit, our new overlords might be obsessed with tearing up rules while the old lot love to make them. But in many ways, they don’t look so different. As they might put it in Brussels: <em> plus ça change</em>.</p>
</description>

 <title>South Africa’s Music: Five Artists You Really Should Be Listening To</title>
 <link>http://www.newsweek.com/south-africas-music-five-artists-you-really-should-be-listening-459203</link>
 <description><p>South African musicians are celebrating a decision by one of the country’s largest broadcasters to introduce a quota in favor of local music on its radio stations.</p>
<p>The South African Broadcasting Corporation (SABC) <a  href="http://www.sabc.co.za/wps/portal/SABC/SABCARTICLE?id=78a944804cbb4c09b142f18d7727b2d8&amp;page_from=PRESS" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> announced Thursday</a> that it will now play 90 percent local music on its 18 radio stations. SABC chief operations officer Hlaudi Motsoeneng said the decision was taken as part of the corporation’s mandate “is to reflect the South African story and music is an important part in ensuring that the SABC fulfils this mandate.”</p>
<p>The decision means that South Africans will be able to hear more of the music produced in the country. In order that the rest of the world doesn’t miss out, <em> Newsweek</em> recommends five South African musicians worth listening to.</p>
<p><strong>1. Ladysmith Black Mambazo</strong></p>
<p>The undisputed kings of South African a cappella, Ladysmith Black Mambazo have released more than 50 albums and accumulated four Grammy awards in their illustrious history. The all-male group has pioneered several styles of music, including isicathamiya—a singing style that originated among black Zulu workers who left their homes and traveled far away to work in the mines of South Africa.</p>
<p><iframe allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/iUH7PM0-cpI" width="560"></iframe></p>
<p><strong>2. Oskido</strong></p>
<p>Oscar Bonginkosi Mdlongwa—commonly known by his stage name Oskido—was another local musician who paid tribute to the SABC’s decision, saying on <a  href="https://www.instagram.com/p/BFS0JtLy54V/?taken-by=oskidoibelieve&amp;hl=en" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> his Instagram account</a> that it marked a “transformation” in the country’s music industry. A DJ and the co-founder of South African record label Kalawa Jazmee Records, Oskido is known for popularizing the Kwaito genre, which emerged in Johannesburg during the 1990s as an Africanized version of house music.</p>
<p><iframe allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/rDTf6CCABsE" width="560"></iframe></p>
<p><strong>3. Hugh Masekela</strong></p>
<p>A world-famous trumpeter whose music protested against the evils of apartheid and slavery, Hugh Masekela brought South African jazz to a global audience. Masekela plied his trade in New York alongside contemporaries including Miles Davis and was trained by Louis Armstrong. He even scored a U.S. No. 1 with his instrumental, <em> Grazin’ in the Grass</em>.</p>
<p><iframe allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/UKcGCObEb28" width="420"></iframe></p>
<p><strong>4. Slikour</strong></p>
<p>A pioneer in South Africa’s popular brand of hip-hop, Slikour—real name Siyabonga Metane—runs a blog, Slikour onLife, in response to the lack of support for local music by the country’s media. The artist <a  href="http://702.co.za/articles/13479/sa-hip-hop-artist-slikour-celebrates-sabc-s-90-local-music-quota" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> told South African radio station 702</a> that he could never have envisaged the quota being implemented. “In the music industry, it’s like [Nelson] Mandela coming out of jail, to keep it real,” he said.</p>
<p><iframe allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/AGbNue3VA6Y" width="420"></iframe></p>
<p><strong>5. Don Laka</strong></p>
<p>Another advocate of kwaita and Afro-jazz, Don Laka was a leading figure of the movement to have local music quotas implemented. Laka, who also co-founded Kalawa Jazmee Records with Oskido, has <a href="https://www.facebook.com/don.laka.73"> described the SABC’s decision</a> as the “death of cultural imperialism.”</p>
<p><iframe allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/04y6Lz1bFMI" width="420"></iframe></p>
</description>

 <title>Would Remaining in the EU Create 790,000 New U.K. jobs?</title>
 <link>http://www.newsweek.com/would-remaining-eu-create-790000-new-uk-jobs-459136</link>
 <description><p><em><img alt="The Conversation" height="1" src="https://counter.theconversation.edu.au/content/59038/count.gif" width="1" />This article was originally published on The Conversation. <a  href="https://theconversation.com/fact-check-790-000-new-jobs-by-2030-if-uk-remains-in-eu-59038" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">Read the original article</a>.</em></p>
<p>"Remaining in Europe will create an extra 790,000 U.K. jobs by the time these kids grow up, so whatever they want to be, they will have the best opportunities to get on in life if we stay in the EU." <strong>Britain Stronger in Europe <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KBvUW3ryS9Y">ad campaign</a></strong></p>
<p>This prediction, which comes from <a  href="http://www.cebr.com/reports/britain-stronger-in-europe/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">a report</a> by the Centre for Economics and Business Research (CEBR), published last October, assumes something which may never happen—namely that the <a  href="https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/2010-to-2015-government-policy-european-single-market/2010-to-2015-government-policy-european-single-market" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">European Single Market</a> will be completed. The CEBR’s broader claim is that the EU’s current project to complete the single market in areas such as transport, tourism, energy and online trade will lead to increased U.K. GDP of €275 billion (£218 billion). The report translates this into the 790,000 jobs.</p>
<p>The trouble is that many of the changes are likely to be resisted by the public because they will cost jobs—initially at least—particularly in sectors that have already suffered over the past few decades, such as energy. To realise the further integration involved, we would need to see a significant change in the <a  href="http://whatukthinks.org/eu/opinion-polls/poll-of-polls/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">national psyche</a>. If we managed this, we would still be at a disadvantage compared to other EU countries because the benefits depend on the free movement of labor. The fact that the U.K. is not within the <a  href="http://www.schengenvisainfo.com/schengen-visa-countries-list/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">Schengen area</a> or the eurozone makes these difficult to realise.</p>
<p><iframe allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="446" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/KBvUW3ryS9Y" width="754"></iframe></p>
<p>Even then, the savings are only of direct benefit to the profit margins of the companies that manage to survive the increased competition. Completing the single market won’t benefit workers as such. Reducing the number of “national” producers across 28 member states to allow the strongest companies to freely expand means redundancies as duplicated jobs are removed. This is similar to what has already happened in the EU. Over the last 25 years, under the <a  href="http://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=uriserv:xy0026" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">Maastricht Treaty</a>, there has been job creation in the U.K. but the labor market has been hollowed out at the same time. We <a  href="http://www.palgrave.com/us/book/9780230392540" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">have lost</a> traditional craft and manufacturing jobs to more competitive EU neighbors, while our market-oriented approach and poorer employment protection <a  href="http://bit.ly/27fQOu5" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">led to</a> employers generating lots of low-paid services jobs.</p>
<p>To ensure a benefit from completing the single market to the population of the U.K. as a whole, profits from the companies who were benefiting would need to be reinvested for the common good. This would require a clear strategic plan for the economy, as opposed to just leaving it to market demand. We would recommend an apprenticeship system that led to sustainable careers, paralleling <a  href="https://www.equalityhumanrights.com/en/our-work-scotland/our-work-scotland/research-scotland/modern-apprenticeships" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">similar schemes</a> in the Nordic countries, Switzerland and Germany. But even then, these schemes have been established for decades and are strongly culturally embedded.</p>
<p>It would help if Britain were closer to the <a  href="http://www.investopedia.com/articles/investing/100714/nordic-model-pros-and-cons.asp" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">Nordic social model</a>, where there is greater empowerment within the workforce and wages are at a reasonable level. This means that employers have to invest in their labor, and apprenticeships are an important part of the picture. The U.K. stands out <a  href="http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/statistics-explained/index.php/Gender_pay_gap_statistics" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">as having</a> one of the largest gender pay gaps in the EU15, and it <a  href="http://www.parliament.scot/S4_EconomyEnergyandTourismCommittee/General%20Documents/Proceedings_v2.pdf" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">clear that</a> the most successful economies not only have wage equality but also high levels of union representation and collective bargaining.</p>
<p><figure class="align-center zoomable"><a  href="https://62e528761d0685343e1c-f3d1b99a743ffa4142d9d7f1978d9686.ssl.cf2.rackcdn.com/files/121628/area14mp/image-20160508-2551-2841u1.jpg" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"><img alt="" src="https://62e528761d0685343e1c-f3d1b99a743ffa4142d9d7f1978d9686.ssl.cf2.rackcdn.com/files/121628/width754/image-20160508-2551-2841u1.jpg" /></a></figure></p>
<p>	<figcaption><span class="caption">The apprentice (and the other one).</span> <span class="attribution"><a  class="source" href="http://www.shutterstock.com/cat.mhtml?lang=en&amp;language=en&amp;ref_site=photo&amp;search_source=search_form&amp;version=llv1&amp;anyorall=all&amp;safesearch=1&amp;use_local_boost=1&amp;autocomplete_id=&amp;search_tracking_id=WLIATPIJRQN-SqOzb4rSPA&amp;searchterm=new%20jobs&amp;show_color_wheel=1&amp;orient=&amp;commercial_ok=&amp;media_type=images&amp;search_cat=&amp;searchtermx=&amp;photographer_name=&amp;people_gender=&amp;people_age=&amp;people_ethnicity=&amp;people_number=&amp;color=&amp;page=1&amp;inline=329573831" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">Phovoir</a></span></figcaption><br /></p>
<p>None of this is an argument for leaving the EU. If the U.K. did so, it would take an awfully long time to put in place new trade agreements and the impact on the economy in the interim would be catastrophic.</p>
<h3>Verdict</h3>
<p>Realising 790,000 jobs from continued EU membership by 2030 depends on completion of the European Single Market. Achieving that depends on getting a deal past the eurosceptic U.K. public and converting economic growth into jobs with a major strategic plan. It is certainly not as simple as saying that the jobs will come if we vote to remain on June 23.</p>
<h3>Review</h3>
<p><em>Nigel Driffield, Professor of International Business, University of Warwick</em></p>
<p>I largely concur with the comments. The essential premise of the argument is one around trade creation. At present, particularly in public procurement and infrastructure projects, the EU is some way off completing the single market. While the spirit of the single market is that equal opportunities are afforded to all EU member states when firms are bidding for such contracts, in practice there is sufficient wiggle room to allow governments to emphasise regional development or other strategic priorities when allocating contracts.</p>
<p>There is a <a  href="http://policyscotland.gla.ac.uk/do-eu-procurement-rules-discriminate-against-uk-and-scottish-construction-interests/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">view that</a> the U.K. is somewhat “fairer” on this say than Germany, such that German firms win U.K. contracts but seldom the reverse. This however is a feature of the austerity and efficiency that is emphasised in U.K. procurement rather than anyone else not playing by the rules.</p>
<p>But as the comment also notes, trade creation implies a degree of trade competition, and there will doubtless be some “losers”—some U.K. firms will gain from further moves to a single market, while others lose out to EU competitors. This I assume is the reference to the job losses, and the degree of migration that might occur. When steel plants closed in Scotland and steel workers moved to Northampton in search of work, this was seen as normal, but for trade creation to yield benefits in full this requires, as the author notes, movement of labor across the EU. In many countries this is seen as problematic at the present time.</p>
<p><em><span><a  href="http://theconversation.com/profiles/abigail-marks-202533" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">Abigail Marks</a> is Professor of Work and Employment Studies at <a  href="http://theconversation.com/institutions/heriot-watt-university" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">Heriot-Watt University</a> and <a  href="http://theconversation.com/profiles/mike-danson-264219" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">Mike Danson</a> is Professor of Enterprise Policy at <a  href="http://theconversation.com/institutions/heriot-watt-university" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">Heriot-Watt University</a>.</span></em></p>

 <title>Young Offenders Filming Crimes For Facebook and Snapchat to ‘Face Tougher Punishments’</title>
 <link>http://www.newsweek.com/young-offenders-filming-crimes-facebook-and-snapchat-face-tougher-punishments-459182</link>
 <description><p>Young offenders in England and Wales who film their crimes to <a href="http://europe.newsweek.com/people-are-texting-emailing-facebooking-and-selfie-ing-while-driving-327507"> post on social media</a> could face tougher punishments under new proposals.</p>
<p>Judges and magistrates would be expected to consider such behavior a “serious aggravating feature” when sentencing offenders aged 10 to 17.</p>
<p>The <a  href="https://www.sentencingcouncil.org.uk/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> Sentencing Council</a> said footage was sometimes used to embarrass, humiliate or blackmail victims and the new guidance aims to reflect the harm caused.</p>
<p>If adopted, it will be the first time the issue has been explicitly covered in guidelines for dealing with young offenders.</p>
<p>It comes a month after two teenage girls were given life sentences for murdering 39-year-old <a  href="http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/05/11/youngsters-who-film-their-crimes-and-post-on-social-media-face-t/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> Angela Wrightson</a> in the north east town of Hartlepool.</p>
<p>The girls, then aged 13 and 14, took photographs of the attack, and uploaded them to the social media application Snapchat.</p>
<p>Draft Sentencing Council guidelines on the “overarching principles” for how courts handle youth criminals list a number of potential “aggravating factors,” which are being consulted on until August 3.</p>
<p>They include “deliberate humiliation of victim, <a href="http://europe.newsweek.com/video-cctv-footage-captures-moment-thief-ran-over-courier-own-van-446302"> including, but not limited to, filming of the offense</a>.”</p>
<p>They also include “deliberately committing the offence before a group of peers with the intent of causing additional distress or circulating details/photos/videos etc of the offense on social media or within peer groups.”</p>
</description>

 <title>Why Is Barclays Launching Its Own Version of Android Pay?</title>
 <link>http://www.newsweek.com/why-barclays-launching-its-own-version-apple-pay-459169</link>
 <description><p>One month after introducing Apple Pay to its U.K. customers, Barclays has announced its own mobile payments system.</p>
<p>The launch of Barclays Contactless Mobile next month is likely to coincide with the arrival of <a href="http://www.newsweek.com/android-pay-set-uk-launch-march-431446"> Android Pay</a>, a similar service that will allow owners of NFC-enabled Android smartphones to make payments at contactless locations around the country. This leads to the question of why the banking giant feels it is necessary to launch its own service.</p>
<p>For Ashok Vaswani, the CEO of Barclays U.K., the launch of Contactless Mobile is about providing “unrivalled” payment options to its customers.</p>
<p>“Giving customers the choice about how to make everyday payments while making it really easy for people to use our service is why we’ve designed this new contactless payment functionality,” Vaswani said in a statement.</p>
<p>Vaswani added that allowing customers to “pay it your way” would serve to help them become more confident using new payment platforms and technologies. It could be argued that such choice could also lead to confusion among its customers.</p>
<p>Barclays customers will have the choice to pay using Contactless Mobile, Apple Pay, the Pingit mobile payment service, the bPay contactless wristband (and <a  href="https://www.bpay.co.uk/home" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> keyfob and sticker)</a>, as well as the usual methods of cheque, credit card, debit card bank transfer and cash.</p>
<p>The introduction of Contactless Mobile has already been described by some as the latest in a series of “bungles” made by Barclays in the mobile payments space. Oliver Smith, a writer at the Memo, noted that Barclays was the last major U.K. bank to integrate Apple Pay, as well as the one noticeable exception from the list of partners for Android Pay’s upcoming U.K. launch.</p>
<p>“It now seems that once again Barclays customers will be forced to use the bank’s own mobile payments offering on Android, rather than Google’s own solution that will be better integrated into Android smartphones,” Smith <a  href="http://www.thememo.com/2016/05/12/deja-vu-android-pay-holdout-barclays-launches-its-own-mobile-payments/" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"> writes</a>.</p>
<p>“Will Barclays eventually buckle and support Android Pay? If history is any guide, we bet it will.”</p>
